data.title: 'Nobel Laureates in Literature: William Faulkner' Quiz
data.meta_description: A Literature > Authors Quiz : One of the world's most prestigious and coveted recognitions is the Nobel Prize, which recognizes individuals and organizations who have made significant contributions in one of six categories: Physics, Chemistry, Medicine, Literature, Peace,...
data.text:
Question #1

In what year was Faulkner awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature "for his powerful and artistically unique contribution to the modern American novel"?

1939

1949

1959

1969

Question #2

The opening line to Faulkner's Nobel Prize acceptance speech was: "The poet's voice need not merely be the record of man, it can be one of the props, the pillars to help him endure and prevail."

True

False

Question #3

Faulkner was born in and grew up in what state in the United States?

Arkansas

Mississippi

Alabama

Missouri

Question #4

What famous work by Faulkner, which he considered a "tour de force", features the difficulties encountered by the Bundren family in its quest to bury Addie Bundren with her "people" in Jefferson, Mississippi?

Sanctuary

Intruder in the Dust

As I Lay Dying

The Town

Question #5

Which of the following novels is not a work by Faulkner?

Light in August

A Farewell to Arms

Soldiers' Pay

The Wishing Tree

Question #6

During World War I, Faulkner served in the United States Marine Corps.

True

False

Question #7

In 1963, William Faulkner won a Pulitzer Prize in Fiction for "A Fable".

True

False

Question #8

Faulkner married what woman who had once been his childhood sweetheart?

Estelle Oldham

Caroline Compson

Cora Tull

Joanna Burden

Question #9

Beginning in 1949, Faulkner worked with Joan Williams, a student and young author, to write what novel that was published in September of 1951?

Knight's Gambit

The Wild Palms

Requiem for a Nun

Miss Zilphia Gant
